Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Hurricane Harvey Rapid Response: In-Situ Barrier Island Storm Impact and Recovery Measurements of Hydrodynamics, Morphodynamics, and Sedimentation Acr. Hog and F. Island TX
Award.AbstractNarration:
Rapid response field measurements of extreme storm impacts to coastal systems are difficult to obtain due to short advance notice times for deployment, potential for instrument failure or loss, and uncertainty in actual storm impact for specific locations. This project advances capabilities to measure detailed hydrodynamic processes (currents and waves) across the surface of barrier island systems impacted by extreme events. The data will provide unprecedented information to enhance and ground-truth predictive modeling capabilities of storm impacts. Detailed analysis of immediate and medium term (weeks to months) recovery of the two selected field sites (Hog and Folletts Islands) will shed further light on post-storm recovery dynamics of barrier island systems that are critical to understand in the context of relative sea level rise and the potential for more frequent and/or intense tropical storms. In turn, this knowledge can help bolster the resiliency of coastal communities.

The research team was able to deploy a set of five "Rapid Response Units" (RRUs) along the central and upper Texas Gulf coastline three days prior to Hurricane Harvey's landfall as a Category 4 storm on August 25, 2017. The RRU sites provide detailed measurements at two locations roughly half way between the landfall point and Galveston, and enable detailed comparative studies of the storm's impacts on these two systems. The RRUs contain pressure transducers to record water level fluctuations and wave heights, tilt current meters to measure current and orbital wave velocities, acoustic Doppler velocimeters, and GoPro time-lapse imaging systems. These data will be interpreted in the context of pre- and post-storm digital elevation models (DEMs) generated using an unmanned aerial system (UAS) and standard photogrammetric processing algorithms. Post-storm rapid response activities also include subaerial and wading-depth real time kinematic (RTK) beach profile transects and surface sediment sampling and coring of washover deposits. An initial program of weekly UAS flights, followed later by monthly surveys, would document recovery of the barrier system following the hurricane.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Coastal systems are constantly changing due to natural forces stemming from water level changes, water waves, and wind. During storm events these forces tend to be more intense, causing more dramatic changes to our coastlines that then set the stage for the slower recovery processes after the storm has passed. Barrier islands are in many ways the first line of defense against storm-induced coastal impacts such as flooding and erosion and thus play an important role in protecting upland development, infrastructure, bay ecosystems, and habitat. Despite their importance, we still do not fully understand some of the complex dynamics responsible for changing barrier islands during storm impact. One of the reasons for this knowledge gap is the scarcity of detailed field data on hydrodynamics and morphodynamics during an event and during the immediate and medium-term aftermath. This project was designed to help fill this gap by analyzing in-situ data of water level changes, waves, and currents collected during hurricane impact on two barrier island systems in Texas along the Gulf of Mexico shoreline in addition to post-storm monitoring of system recovery.

Hurricane Harvey struck the central Texas Gulf Coast as a Category 4 storm on August 25, 2017. In advance of landfall, the Texas COAstal STorm Rapid Response (COASTRR) team, consisting of researchers from Texas A&M University and Rice University, deployed instrumentation to collect high-resolution in-situ hydrodynamic measurements across two barrier island transects on the upper Texas Gulf Coast. Digital elevation models for the selected project sites were created from multiple unmanned aerial system flights and real-time kinematic GPS surveys on the ground before and immediately after storm impact. Complementary surface sediment samples as well as push-cores of the storm deposits were collected to link the measured storm hydrodynamics with morphodynamic and sedimentary processes.

This was the first hurricane deployment of newly-developed rapid response instrumentation units used to measure water level fluctuations, waves, and currents during the height of a storm. The units consisted of slotted PVC wells outfitted with internal pressure sensors to measure waves and water level changes and topped with a new tilt current meter prototype to measure flow velocities designed to withstand harsh conditions during storm impact.

Results at the two locations showed that very low-frequency wave motions enhanced by storm activity dominated the surf zone that can basically extend across an entire barrier island during such an extreme event. The measuring campaign revealed that the processes that govern erosion, overwash, and deposition associated with storm impacts on barrier islands are influenced significantly by nonlinear energy transfers between wave motions of different frequencies (sea-swell, infragravity, and sub-infragravity waves). The low-frequency water level fluctuations are of specific interest since they become the controlling factor for the water depth over a barrier island during storm impact. Since water depth determines where waves break and dissipate their energy, detailed knowledge of processes that determine where this release of energy happens is important to assess where sediment erosion and accretion occur. One of the sites investigated in this project included an elevated cut through a barrier island connecting the Gulf with the back-bay. The cut was activated during elevated hurricane water levels and encountered up to 0.5 meters of sediment deposition during the event. Sediment cores of the deposited material revealed layers of reworked offshore sediment deposited by infragravity wave bores during the height of the storm. Usually such details cannot be captured by simply comparing pre- and post-storm data.

Obtaining such detailed measurements during storms is crucial for further improvements of predictive models and tools that help forecast impacts to coastal systems in the event of approaching storms. More accurate predictions will lead to better design considerations for coastal infrastructure and help reduce the risk to life and property. Finally, a better understanding of the recovery processes after storm impact will help improve management strategies to create more resilient coastal communities.
